story.storybody:
From alleged phone calls from India's most wanted terrorist Dawood Ibrahim to misuse of his position to benefit his family, Maharashtra Revenue Minister Eknath Khadse is in a whirlpool of controversy. A sting operation conducted by India Today has now nailed the minister further. 
 
It's the land scam controversy that has cornered the minister beyond anything else. Khadse has denied any wrongdoings.

India Today Impact: Heat on Khadse as Mumbai Police launch fresh probe into Dawood calls  

However, a sting operation by India Today has revealed that Khadse left no stones unturned to intimidate and silence whistleblower Hemant Gawande, who had red-flagged the land grabbing by the senior Maharashtra minister.

KHADSE'S 'SARKAR RAAJ' EXPOSED

Gawande has furnished a page he says is from the Pune police dairy which mentions that a police inspector had been pressurised by Khadse to register a case against the whistleblower.

Since a piece of unverified paper couldn't be conclusive, India Today met the police officer - Hiraman Shirsaat, who had made the note against the Maharashtra minister.

Show proofs against me and I will quit politics: Eknath Khadse

Here's how the conversations went:

India Today (IT): We wanted to verify this note from the station diary. We accessed this through RTI, want to verify it as we don't want our report to be incorrect.

Shirsaat: This is correct.

IT: It says case was registered at the behest of Eknath Khadse.

Shirsaat: What's written is correct. It has my signature.

IT: Have seen such a police officer for the first time, who is writing against his minister....

Shirsaat: Why should I be scared? I'll stay in jail...

IT: But...can a minister pressurise anyone like this?

Shirsaat: I wrote whatever he told me.

IT: We are from India Today, sir.

Shirsaat: That's okay. What he told me, I wrote it down and gave it to all departments in writing that he  asked me to file a police complaint, please give me the details. The truth is there in it, nothing else.

Shirsaat claimed that minister Khadse summoned all police officers to a guest house in Pune and then pressurised them to take action against the whistleblower but he refused to oblige.

Minister Khadse allegedly flew into a rage threatening to take the case into his own hands and get the agricultural department involved.

SOLID CASE AGAINST KHADSE

India Today reporters then asked the cop about the land grab allegation against Khadse. Inspector Shirsaat backed the whistleblower saying he has a solid case against the minister.

IT: What about the land grab issue... the minister usurped 3.5 acre land...is this true?

Shirsaat: Hemant Gawande should know this better...Gawande won't shout without any firm evidence...he is a coward. I tried to make him speak for nearly a year...now he has papers, that's why he is speaking else who would raise voice against a minister?

However, the Pune Police did in fact register a case against Hemant Gawande on 31 January last year finding nothing so far against the whistleblower.

The question now is can minister Khadse survive this fresh charge of misusing power to silence an inconvenient voice?
